bio.p: Christian Delageis a historian and a documentary film maker. He is a professor at the University of Paris 8 and teaches as well at Sciences Po (Paris). He is a regular visiting professor at the Cardozo School of Law in New York City and the author ofLa vérité par l’image: De Nuremberg au process Milosevic, forthcoming in English translation from the University of Pennsylvania Press.

The film was conceived as an attempt to synthesize into twenty-five minutes those hearings of the Klaus Barbie trial dealing with the circumstances of the arrest and deportation of the Izieu children. Anne Grynberg, the sociologist Alain Bancaud, Sabine Zlatin's attorney, Roland Rappaport, Vincent Guigueno, and myself were given exceptional authorization by the Tribunal de grande instance de Paris and the Institut national de l'audiovisuel to view about twelve hours of the trial's film archives.

These multicasts, started by the channel Canal + en France, allow viewers both to see a prerecorded program that took place live and to see a missed episode at a later date. Fans of the TV series today move constantly between live broadcasts, DVDs, and Internet downloads of yet-to-be broadcast episodes in order to find out what will happen before the day it is supposed to happen.
